column5: I’ve really found my home in this fandom

column1: pinkesbaum 159426971090 "2017-04-10 21:04:05 GMT" https://pinkesbaum.tumblr.com/post/159426971090/authorities-reportedly-detaining-and-killing-gay "sullengirlalmlghty: sullengirlalmlghty:   More than 100 gay men have been detained “in connection with their nontraditional sexual orientation
column2: or suspicion of such
column3: ” according to the New York Times
column4: which cites the opposition newspaper Novaya Gazeta. The Russian newspaper says it confirmed the news with government officials and an analyst of the region also confirmed the news to the Times with her own sources. Three men are known to have been murdered
column5: although the real number is likely to be higher.  in almost every genocide
column6: the first “act” is the rounding up and killing of a group of men
column7: specifically.  In “root and branch” genocides they [”civilian men of ‘battle age’”] are often the first group to be separated out and massacred
column8: paving the way for the murder of women
column10: and elderly men. In more common articulations of genocide
column12: they can be the only group slated for outright massacre
column15: and elderly men suffer a range of alternative fates involving rape
column20: and expulsion. Gender and the Future of Genocide Studies and Prevention   as the rest of this article explains this isn’t to say that men have it worst in a genocide
column21: but that it’s important when you see a very common red flag for genocide to pay attention to the “conflict” in case any more markers of an impending genocide occur.  the g word is really loaded and i’m not bringing this up because i want to start an avalanche of “CHECHNYA IS COMMITTING GENOCIDE AGAINST GAY PEOPLE” fear mongering (that is the absolute last thing that i want). it’s just not possible to prevent any genocide without questioning whether a current conflict might eventually get there. and i do not think it’s nothing that genocide watch is reporting on this.  UPDATE 4/10/17 Chechnya has opened concentration camps for gay men   Gay men arrested in a ‘purge’ in the Russian region of Chechnya are being held in concentration camp-style prisons
column22: reports have alleged. Early reports emerged earlier this month that gay people are being targeted in the region
column23: which is part of Russia but has substantial autonomy. Russian newspapers and human rights groups report that more than 100 gay men have been detained “in connection with their non-traditional sexual orientation
column24: or suspicion of such” as part of a purge. Several people were also reportedly feared dead following violent raids. In a chilling response
column25: a Chechen government spokesperson denied that there are any gay people to detain
column26: insisting that “you can’t detain and harass someone who doesn’t exist in the republic”. The Kremlin denied any knowledge of a purge. But reports have since emerged that the men arrested are being kept in horrific concentration camp prisons
column27: where violent abuse and torture is common. Based on interviews with eyewitnesses and survivors
column28: Novaya Gazeta reports that a secret prison has been set up in the town of Argun to detain the men arrested in the purge. One man who was released from the camp told the newspaper that he was subjected to violent “interrogations” at the camp
column29: as Chechen officials attempted to get him to confess the names and locations of more gay men. The officials also seized his mobile phone
column30: targeting his network of contacts regardless of whether they were gay or not. The camp was reportedly set up by Chechen forces in a former military headquarters in the town. The newspaper reports allegations that the Speaker of the Parliament of Chechnya was among officials to visit the site
column31: though the claims have not been substantiated. The detainees face electric shock torture and violent beatings
column32: while some of them have been held to ransom and used to extort their families. Tanya Lokshina of Human Rights Watch wrote: “For several weeks now
column33: a brutal campaign against LGBT people has been sweeping through Chechnya. She continued: “Law enforcement and security agency officials under control of the ruthless head of the Chechen Republic
column35: have rounded up dozens of men on suspicion of being gay
column36: torturing and humiliating the victims. “Some of the men have forcibly disappeared. Others were returned to their families barely alive from beatings. At least three men apparently have died since this brutal campaign began.” She added: “These days
column37: very few people in Chechnya dare speak to human rights monitors or journalists even anonymously because the climate of fear is overwhelming and people have been largely intimidated into silence. “Filing an official complaint against local security officials is extremely dangerous
column38: as retaliation by local authorities is practically inevitable. “It is difficult to overstate just how vulnerable LGBT people are in Chechnya
column39: where homophobia is intense and rampant. “LGBT people are in danger not only of persecution by the authorities but also of falling victim to ‘honour killings’ by their own relatives for tarnishing family honour.” What Can We Do?   Alexander Artmyev from Amnesty International spoke to Metro.co.uk. He said that people who are not in Russia can help by joining the charity’s Urgent Action on Chechnya. The action encourages people to write in Russian or your own language to Chairman of the Investigation Committee and Acting Head of the Investigation Committee for the Chechen Republic. Amnesty has also asked the letter
column40: which should ask for an investigation and appeal for protection for LGBT individuals
column41: to be copied into Human Rights groups and diplomatic missions from your country. " False link

pinkesbaum 159271541430 "2017-04-06 18:11:12 GMT" https://pinkesbaum.tumblr.com/post/159271541430/breaking-federal-court-rules-employers-cannot "gaywrites:  The Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 8-3 today that discriminating against an employee for their sexual orientation violates Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Lambda Legal took the case on behalf of Kimberly Hively
column2: a community college instructor who was fired for being a lesbian.  Some history on Hively’s case:   In August of 2014
column3: Kimberly Hively sued Ivy Tech Community College
column4: arguing that the school violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 when it denied her full-time employment and promotions after she had been seen kissing her then-girlfriend in the parking lot of the school. The trial court dismissed Hively’s lawsuit and held that Title VII — which prohibits employers from discriminating against employees on the basis of sex
column8: and religion — does not protect employees from antigay discrimination. In April 2015
column9: Lambda Legal appealed to the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals
column10: seeking reversal and reinstatement of Hively’s complaint. A three-judge panel ruled against Hively in July 2016
column11: but Lambda Legal requested a rehearing of the case by the full panel of the Seventh Circuit – all eleven judges. On October 11
column15: Employment Fairness Program Director for Lambda Legal
column17: to ask that the court overturn its prior decisions limiting the reach of Title VII.  The Seventh Circuit is now the highest court to rule in Hively’s favor. In other words: this is a big deal.  " False link

column1: pinkesbaum 159229295300 "2017-04-05 15:09:51 GMT" https://pinkesbaum.tumblr.com/post/159229295300/click-here-to-support-getting-kyla-to-cali-by-n "hyperbali:  So. Here we go! As some of you might know
column2: I’ve been in…not the greatest conditions
column3: and after some talking with Dani
column4: I think the best option for me at the moment is to haul up and move to California. I’ll post the same text here as I’ve got there:   My name is Kyla
column5: and I could use your help.About two years ago
column6: my life was completely uprooted. Due to some issues with my family
column8: after some quick planning and help from friends
column9: I was able to start finding my footing.Unfortunately
column10: the changes were small; what was meant to be a temporary solution to a serious problem is taking its toll on my health and well-being. This is all the space I have to myself; a couch
column12: and a closet with my life crammed into it. I eat here
column13: I sleep here–every piece of art I’ve done for the past two years
column15: has been done from the arm of this couch. Being in such a cramped space has affected my health to the point of needing regular visits with a chiropractor.In a shared house with frequently inconsiderate housemates
column17: and absolutely no privacy or storage to myself
column18: I’ve decided enough is enough.I have a place to stay in California
column19: and I will have a job waiting for me–all I need is the funding to get there.The $3700 I’m asking for will cover:  - Airfare - Transportation - Packing supplies - Baggage feesThe sooner I can get out of this situation and start over again
column20: the better. I appreciate any help you can offer–and thank you for taking the time to read this.   Please help
column21: if you can–or spread the word! I’d really appreciate it. (But lord
column22: if you know me on Facebook
column23: please don’t let it anywhere near there–I have coworkers on that site and I’d really prefer this not getting anywhere near my work life until I’m ready to put in my two weeks.) " False link

column1: pinkesbaum 159192659275 "2017-04-04 15:55:59 GMT" https://pinkesbaum.tumblr.com/post/159192659275/petition-for-the-writers-producers-of-vld-to "mcclaln:  The goal of this petition is to get precise ages for all the main characters from the Dreamworks animated series Voltron: Legendary Defender. The writers and producers of Legendary Defender have been unnecessarily vague about the ages of the main characters - Allura
column2: Hunk
column3: Lance
column6: and Shiro - despite fans’ asking for canon ages since the first season aired in June of 2016. Up until now
column7: the answers fans have gotten have been vague
column8: and frankly a large portion of the fanbase finds this ridiculous. Why keep such basic character facts a secret? Revealing the ages of these characters won’t spoil any of the plot details that are to come in future seasons
column9: and only serves as an inconvenience to fans. Other animated children’s shows such as Star vs. the Forces of Evil and Gravity Falls have confirmed their character’s ages with no repercussions. If anything
column10: it only makes fans more willing to engage with and continue supporting the show. The recent video in which Joaquim Dos Santos refers to Princess Allura
column12: has caused tidal waves amongst fans as a majority of the show’s fanbase had interpreted interactions between Allura and Shiro
column13: another one of the main characters
column14: as romantic. The problem here is that in a video from San Diego Comic Con 2016
column17: and Dos Santos told fans Shiro was 25. As most people know
column18: a 25 year old and a teenager should not be interacting romantically. So what are we
column20: supposed to make of this? It makes us insecure
column21: it makes us distrust the writers and producers of the show
column23: and it has made many fans distance themselves completely from the show. The goal with this petition is to get answers. The fanbase wants to know the ages of the characters
column24: a harmless fact that will not spoil any future plot details. What will be achieved by giving the fans precise ages? We will start trusting and believing in the team behind Voltron: Legendary Defender again
column25: we will be more inclined to engage with the show and share it with friends & family
column26: and we will keep supporting the show. Hopefully this get enough signatures to garner the attention of the show’s creators. Perhaps
column27: once they see how many of us are dissatisfied
column28: they will stop with these ridiculously vague statements and give us some numbers.  SIGN HERE " False link

column1: pinkesbaum 159038472630 "2017-03-31 14:35:43 GMT" https://pinkesbaum.tumblr.com/post/159038472630/transgender-wwii-veteran-comes-out-as-a-woman-at "transqueermediaexchange:  A transgender World War II veteran proves it’s never too late to live life truthfully. Patricia Davies
column2: from Leicestershire
column3: England
column4: didn’t decide to transition into a female until she turned 90 years old. Davies — born Peter — has known she was a woman since she was just a toddler. “I’ve known I was transgender since I was 3 years old. I knew a girl called Patricia
column5: and I decided I wanted to be known by that name but it didn’t stick
column6: ” Davies told Caters News Agency. Davies kept her identity a secret for most of her life for fear she would be shunned by her peers or forced to undergo electric shock treatment. “The atmosphere [around being transgender] was not safe. People did not understand what transgender was
column7: ” Davies said. Davies — who served in the army between April 1945 and 1948 — said coming out as transgender would have categorized her as a homosexual
column8: which wouldn’t have been accepted in the army. Despite losing friends and cheating death while serving in the armed forces
column9: she says she’s glad she got to have the experience. “I feel quite proud having served during the war and having done military service
column10: in particular during the trouble in Palestine
column13: eventually came out to her supportive wife in 1987. Her wife
column14: to whom she was married for 63 years
column15: bought Davies jewelry and dresses that she could wear in private. Sadly
column16: her wife passed away six years ago. “I was 60 when it all came pouring out to my wife
column17: she was very sympathetic and helped me all the way
column18: but we agreed to keep it quiet
column20: who first learned about transgender identity from a TV show sometime in the 1970s. When Davies first came out to her wife
column21: she decided to wear high heels but was deterred when teenagers saw her and threw eggs at her window. Now a nonagenarian
column22: Davies has begun taking estrogen to move her transition forward and has come out to her community. “It feels like a weight has been lifted off my shoulders. I was living a lie
column23: ” she told Caters. “I have been keeping quiet. I have slowly started to tell some of my neighbors. Everybody said
column26: ‘” she added. Patricia was inspired to make the big change from male to female after seeing the romantic comedy film “Boy Meets Girl
column27: ” which features transgender characters. Now that transgender people are portrayed often in film and on TV
column28: Davies feels more comfortable being herself. “It’s not 100 percent safe now but it’s much better than it was. People that I have told seem to be very accommodating and haven’t thrown abuse at me
column29: ” she said. “I joined the Women’s Institute. I socialize with them and have a natter [long chat]. I’m having a great time. I have a new lease on life
